Setting Access Rights Exceptions

Deny records are rarely used. However, they can be used to create exceptions to currently assigned rights. For example, assume that a new person has been added to the Testers group, but has not yet been trained to update the tests. In this situation, you may want to grant the user most, but not all, of the access rights assigned to that group. To list the exceptions, you create a deny record.

It is recommended that you avoid creating deny records. However, if you do decide to deny rights:

  • Never allow any node on an Access Rights dialog to have only deny rights records. If a deny record is the only record for a node, anyone not specifically granted access rights for that node has no access to that type of object at that level (unless ownership or group privileges are in effect).

  • Always make sure that the deny rights records for any node precede the grant rights records for that node. Otherwise, the exception will not occur. If the application finds a grant record that allows a user to perform an operation before finding a deny record that prevents the user from performing it, the user will be allowed to perform the operation.

  • Be aware that the Windows client and the Cross-Platform client interpret the Deny checkbox differently. Unchecked items are interpreted as valid in the Windows client, while checked items are interpreted as valid in the Cross-Platform client.

To create an exception:

  1. From an Access Rights dialog, click Add. The Assign Access Rights To dialog opens.

  2. Select the user who will be an exception within a group.

  3. Select Deny.

  4. Click OK to return to the Access Rights dialog.

    5. Caution: Never select Deny to create an exception to a group unless that group has already been granted access for this same node.

  5. Select and/or clear the appropriate check boxes.

  6. Drag the deny record to the top of the list in the Access Rights dialog. Alternatively, you can use the Move Up and Move Down buttons to perform this operation.

  7. Click OK.

Note: A grant record with no check boxes selected is different from a deny record with all check boxes selected, even though both may stop a user from performing the same operations. For a given node at a given level, the application examines grant records until it finds one that gives the user permission to perform an operation or until all the grant records have been examined. If membership in one group does not allow the user to perform the operation but membership in a second group does, the user can perform that operation. However, if a deny record for that node forbids the user from performing an operation, the application immediately determines that the user cannot perform that operation. Other grant records for the node that might have allowed the user to perform the operation are not considered.
